IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: LIVEWELL COLORADO'S MISSION IS TO PREVENT AND REDUCE OBESITY.
IRS990.MissionDesc: LIVEWELL COLORADO IS A STATEWIDE NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION COMMITTED TO PREVENTING AND REDUCING OBESITY IN COLORADO BY PROMOTING HEALTHY EATING AND ACTIVE LIVING. SEE SCHEDULE O FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION.IN ADDITION TO EDUCATING AND SUPPORTING PEOPLE TO MAKE HEALTHY CHOICES, LIVEWELL COLORADO FOCUSES ON POLICY, ENVIRONMENTAL AND LIFESTYLE CHANGES THAT REMOVE BARRIERS AND INCREASE ACCESS TO HEALTHY BEHAVIORS. WORKING IN PARTNERSHIP WITH OBESITY PREVENTION INITIATIVES ACROSS THE STATE, LIVEWELL COLORADO AIMS TO PROVIDE EVERY COLORADAN WITH ACCESS TO HEALTHY FOODS AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY TO MAKE COLORADO THE HEALTHIEST STATE IN THE NATION.
IRS990.Desc: LOCAL INITIATIVES: COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS- LIVEWELL COLORADO'S (LWC) COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM FUNDS COMMUNITY COALITIONS WORKING ON HEALTHY EATING AND ACTIVE LIVING STRATEGIES AT THE LOCAL LEVEL. AWARDED $1.6 MILLION IN FUNDING TO 16 COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE STATE THAT REPRESENT LOW SOCIO-ECONOMIC AREAS WITH HIGHER OBESITY RATES; PROVIDED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR SHARED KNOWLEDGE AND COLLABORATIONS TO INCREASE SUSTAINABILITY INCLUDING COMMUNITY VISITS, PHONE CONSULTATIONS, WEBINARS, ROUNDTABLE DISCUSSIONS, TRAININGS AND MEETINGS THAT PROMOTE INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF HEALTHY FOOD, ACTIVE COMMUNITY ENVIRONMENTS, AND GRASSROOTS ADVOCACY. SEE SCHEDULE O FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION.SUPPORTED TARGETED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE RELATED TO COMMUNITY ORGANIZING AND ENGAGING/EMPOWERING THE TARGET POPULATION.COLLABORATED WITH LOCAL PARTNERS AND DISTRIBUTED $132K IN PARTNER GRANTS TO INCREASE YOUTH PARTICIPATION IN LOCAL RECREATION CENTERS BY CONNECTING YOUTH TO RECREATION CENTER PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT AND BUILT ENVIRONMENT IMPROVEMENTS. THE YOUTH-DRIVEN HEALTHY RECREATION CENTERS COLLECTIVE GRANT, WHICH WAS IMPLEMENTED IN DENVER'S SWANSEA, ST. CHARLES AND STAPLETON RECREATION CENTERS, HELPED TURN REC CENTERS INTO PLACES WHERE YOUTH CHOOSE TO SPEND TIME AND LEARN NEW SKILLS FOR HEALTHY EATING AND ACTIVE LIVING. IN A SURVEY, 92 PERCENT OF PARTICIPATING YOUTH REPORTED EATING MORE FRUITS AND VEGETABLES, 85 PERCENT SAID THEY HAD CUT BACK ON ELECTRONIC DEVICES IN FAVOR OF MORE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND 70 PERCENT STARTED COOKING MEALS WITH THEIR FAMILIES. THIS PARTNERSHIP GRANT WAS AN EIGHTEEN-MONTH COLLABORATION BETWEEN LIVEWELL AND SEVEN PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS IN THE METRO AREA. LIVEWELL @SCHOOL FOOD INITIATIVE- INVESTED OVER $1.06 MILLION IN PROGRAMS TO TRANSITION SCHOOL DISTRICT KITCHEN OPERATIONS TO OFFER FRESHLY PREPARED STUDENT MEALS. CONDUCTED SCHOOL MEAL ASSESSMENTS WITH RECOMMENDATIONS FOR SCHOOL DISTRICTS, PRESENTED CULINARY WORKSHOPS TO TEACH FUNDAMENTALS OF SCRATCH COOKING, AND DEDICATED A TEAM OF ON-SITE CHEF CONSULTANTS TO PARTNER WITH DISTRICTS THROUGHOUT THE SCHOOL YEAR IN CREATING AND IMPLEMENTING SUSTAINABLE CULINARY ACTION PLANS TO IMPROVE STUDENT MEALS. IMPLEMENTED PROGRAM EVALUATION TOOLS TO ASSESS SUSTAINABLE CHANGES. TRANSFORMED AND REFINED THE SCHOOL FOOD INITIATIVE TO BETTER ALIGN WITH SCHOOL SCHEDULES AND THE SCHOOL FOOD ENVIRONMENT, INCLUDING A COMPLETE FACELIFT OF THE MATERIALS, PROCESSES AND PROFESSIONAL TEAM. AN INAUGURAL SUSTAINABILITY WORKSHOP WAS INTRODUCED TO HELP SCHOOL DISTRICTS TO EXTEND THE YEAR-ONE HANDS-ON COACHING AND TRAINING FOR MULTIPLE YEARS. HEAL CITIES & TOWNS CAMPAIGN - CONTINUED EXPANDING THE LIVEWELL COLORADO HEAL CITIES AND TOWNS CAMPAIGN IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE COLORADO MUNICIPAL LEAGUE TO ENCOURAGE MUNICIPALITIES TO PASS AND IMPLEMENT LOCAL HEALTHY EATING AND ACTIVE LIVING RELATED POLICIES. GREW TO 42 PARTICIPATING MUNICIPALITIES DURING THE YEAR, INCLUDING CARBONDALE, CENTENNIAL, GLENWOOD SPRINGS, GREELEY, KIOWA, MONTROSE, RIFLE AND SAGUACHE. HOSTED THE THIRD ANNUAL HEAL SUMMIT, WHICH BROUGHT TOGETHER MUNICIPAL AND COMMUNITY LEADERS TO LEARN AND SHARE BEST POLICY AND ENVIRONMENTAL PRACTICES TO CREATE HEALTHIER CITIES AND TOWNS. THE EVENT DREW MORE THAN 100 ATTENDEES.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: COMMUNICATIONS: LIVEWELL COLORADO'S COMMUNICATIONS AND MARKETING STRATEGY INCLUDED COMMUNITY-BASED SOCIAL MARKETING AND COMMUNICATIONS CAMPAIGNS WHICH CONSISTED OF MASS MEDIA, MEDIA RELATIONS, SOCIAL MEDIA, COMMUNITY EVENTS, AND INTERVENTIONS AIMED TO INCREASE HEALTHY EATING AND ACTIVE LIVING (HEAL) BEHAVIORS. SEE SCHEDULE O FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION.ENGAGED OVER 65,000 FACEBOOK FRIENDS AND 5,000 TWITTER FOLLOWERS TO DATE WHO SHARE ONLINE HEALTHY EATING AND ACTIVE LIVING (HEAL) INFORMATION WITH THEIR NETWORKS THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA. IN 2015, LIVEWELL EVOLVED TO A NEW COMMUNICATIONS APPROACH FOCUSED ON BUILDING AND MOBILIZING CHAMPIONS FOR HEALTH, RAISING AWARENESS ABOUT BARRIERS TO HEALTHY AND AFFORDABLE FOOD AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND ENCOURAGING ACTIONS THAT ADVANCE THE OPPORTUNITY FOR MORE COLORADANS TO HAVE ACCESS TO HEALTHY LIVING. COMMUNICATIONS ACTIVITIES ALSO SUPPORTED THE ORGANIZATIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE NEEDED TO SHARE INFORMATION, PROMOTE THE WORK OF OUR COMMUNITY AND STATE PARTNERS, AND MOBILIZE THE NETWORK OF ADVOCATES AND CHAMPIONS AND KEEP THEM ENGAGED.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: POLICY AND ADVOCACY: HOSTED SIXTH ANNUAL DAY AT THE CAPITOL IN FEBRUARY, INCLUDING A HEALTHY MEET-AND-GREET BREAKFAST AND A PANEL OF POLICYMAKERS WHO INFLUENCE HEAL POLICY IN A VARIETY OF WAYS. CONTINUED TO SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE COLORADO FOOD POLICY NETWORK (COFPN) AND ITS LEADERSHIP COUNCIL IN PARTNERSHIP WITH CSU EXTENSION. THE COFPN BROUGHT TOGETHER THE 18 LOCAL FOOD POLICY COUNCILS FROM ACROSS THE STATE TO PROMOTE HEALTHY, COMMUNITY-BASED, ECONOMICALLY VIABLE FOOD SYSTEMS IN COLORADO THAT ENSURE ALL RESIDENTS HAVE ACCESS TO AFFORDABLE, NUTRITIOUS FOOD. SEE SCHEDULE O FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION.CORE AREAS OF FOCUS WERE BUILDING THE CAPACITY OF LOCAL FOOD SYSTEMS COALITIONS TO EFFECT POLICY CHANGE AND ADVANCING STATE LEVEL POLICIES, INVESTMENTS AND STRATEGIES THROUGH A COLLECTIVE APPROACH. WORKED WITH A COALITION OF PARTNERS TO ADVOCATE FOR DEDICATED FUNDING FOR SAFE ROUTES TO SCHOOL INFRASTRUCTURE AND EDUCATION, FOR WHICH $2.5 MILLION WAS COMMITTED ANNUALLY. SUCCESSFULLY ENSURED THE DEFEAT OF A PROPOSAL TO REPEAL THE STATE SODA TAX. WEIGHED IN ON FEDERAL POLICY ISSUES INCLUDING CHILD NUTRITION REAUTHORIZATION AND A FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION PROPOSAL TO LIST SUGAR ON FOOD NUTRITION LABELS. LAUNCHED A NEW PILOT PROJECT (PASS PROJECT: POLICY ASSISTANCE, STRATEGY SUPPORT) TO SUPPORT POLICY CHANGES IN THE COMMUNITIES WHERE LIVEWELL HAS EXISTING PARTNERS. THE PROJECT IS TO PROVIDED TARGETED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO ASSIST IN STRATEGIZING, PASSING, AND IMPLEMENTING COMMUNITY-BASED, LOCAL-LEVEL HEAL POLICY INITIATIVES. CREATED AN INAUGURAL LIVEWELL PUBLIC POLICY COMMITTEE (WHICH INCLUDED DIVERSE REPRESENTATION FROM URBAN AND RURAL COLORADO) TO ADVANCE EFFORTS THAT WILL LEVERAGE LOCAL-LEVEL PARTNERS TO INFORM AND ADVOCATE ON BEHALF OF A SHARED, STATEWIDE POLICY PLATFORM. CONVENED A BROAD AND DIVERSE GROUP OF PARTNERS TO APPLY FOR A FEDERAL GRANT FROM THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE WHICH WILL GIVE LOW-INCOME FAMILIES THE ABILITY TO PURCHASE MORE COLORADO-GROWN FRESH FRUITS AND VEGETABLES AT FARMERS MARKETS THROUGHOUT THE STATE.

Form990ScheduleAPartVIGrp.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: SCHEDULE A, PART III, LINE 12, EXPLANATION OF OTHER INCOME:
Form990ScheduleAPartVIGrp.ExplanationTxt: MISCELLANEOUS INCOME - 2012 AMOUNT: $ 1,289. 2013 AMOUNT: $ 136. 2014 AMOUNT: $ 543. 2015 AMOUNT: $ 1,558. CONSULTING INCOME - 2012 AMOUNT: $ 4,190. 2013 AMOUNT: $ 4,079.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE ORGANIZATION APPLIES A MORE-LIKELY-THAN-NOT MEASUREMENT METHODOLOGY TO REFLECT THE FINANCIAL STATEMENT IMPACT OF UNCERTAIN TAX POSITIONS TAKEN OR EXPECTED TO BE TAKEN IN A TAX RETURN. AFTER EVALUATING THE TAX POSITIONS TAKEN, NONE ARE CONSIDERED TO BE UNCERTAIN; THEREFORE, NO AMOUNTS HAVE BEEN RECOGNIZED AS OF DECEMBER 31, 2015 AND 2014. IF INCURRED, INTEREST AND PENALTIES ASSOCIATED WITH TAX POSITIONS ARE RECORDED IN THE PERIOD ASSESSED AS ADMINISTRATION AND GENERAL EXPENSE. NO INTEREST OR PENALTIES HAVE BEEN ASSESSED AS OF DECEMBER 31, 2015 OR 2014. TAX YEARS THAT REMAIN SUBJECT TO EXAMINATION INCLUDE 2012 THROUGH THE CURRENT YEAR.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE GRANTS ARE MADE TO OTHER SECTION 501(C)(3) ORGANIZATIONS AND GOVERNMENT AGENCIES THAT SHARE THE MISSION AND VISION OF LIVEWELL COLORADO. STAFF CONDUCTS SITE VISITS, RECEIVES EVALUATION REPORTS, AND CONDUCTS TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CALLS TO MONITOR PROGRESS OF INVESTMENTS IN COMMUNITY COALITION WORK. THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS ALSO RECEIVES PERIODIC PRESENTATIONS FROM VARIOUS RECIPIENTS DESCRIBING HOW THE FUNDS HAVE BEEN USED.

THE COMPANY MAY AWARD AN EXECUTIVE A PERFORMANCE BONUS OF UP TO 15% OF THE EXECUTIVE'S BASE SALARY. THE DETERMINATION OF WHETHER TO AWARD A PERFORMANCE BONUS TO EXECUTIVE, THE AMOUNT OF ANY PERFORMANCE BONUS AND THE TIMING OF ANY PERFORMANCE BONUS SHALL BE IN THE BOARD'S SOLE DISCRETION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 11
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: FORM 990 IS INITIALLY REVIEWED BY THE FINANCE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS AND THEN PROVIDED TO THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS FOR APPROVAL PRIOR TO SUBMISSION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 12C
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: BOARD AND STAFF MEMBERS ARE REQUIRED TO REVIEW AND SIGN THE CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY ANNUALLY. THE FINANCE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MONITORING AND ENFORCING COMPLIANCE WITH THE CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY. AT EACH BOARD MEETING THE BOARD MEMBERS ARE ASKED IF ANY NEW CONFLICTS OF INTEREST HAVE ARISEN. THE BOARD MEMBERS RECUSE THEMSELVES FROM VOTING IF ANY CONFLICTS OF INTEREST EXIST.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 15A
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: IN 2015, THE ENTIRE BOARD OF DIRECTORS REVIEWED THE PERFORMANCE OF THE PRESIDENT AND CEO AND A COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS REVIEWED AND RECOMMENDED ADJUSTMENTS TO THE COMPENSATION FOR THE PRESIDENT AND CEO. THE FULL BOARD DISCUSSED AND APPROVED THE COMPENSATION ADJUSTMENT AND THE ACCOUNTING OFFICE WAS ADVISED OF THE ADJUSTMENT BY THE CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD VIA SIGNED MEMO. INITIAL CEO COMPENSATION WAS SET WITH THE USE OF SURVEYS FROM WELL ESTABLISHED SOURCES, INCLUDING THE MOUNTAIN STATES EMPLOYERS COUNCIL (MSEC) SURVEY AS A PRIMARY LOCAL SOURCE. THE FINANCE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS REVIEWS THE ADJUSTMENTS TO STAFF SALARIES DURING THE ANNUAL BUDGET PROCESS, AND THE CHANGE TO SALARIES ARE ADJUSTED BASED UPON ANNUAL SALARY SURVEY DATA FROM MSEC AND OTHER SOURCES. THE PRESIDENT AND CEO APPROVES THE COMPENSATION FOR VP'S AND KEY EMPLOYEES. THIS PROCESS WAS LAST UNDERTAKEN FOR EACH PERSON IN 2015.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION C, LINE 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE ORGANIZATION'S GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY, AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS ARE AVAILABLE UPON REQUEST.
